text: Donald Trump and many of the world's
most powerful leaders will be heading to
Hamburg for this latest g20 summit and
it's not overstating things to say but
the next few days may decide how the
world responds to some of its most
pressing problems I say that because
there is a genuine divide between Donald
Trump and some of the other leaders will
be here in Hamburg as to how to respond
to issues of immigration climate change
and trade there will also be some who
question the way that Donald Trump sort
of look at Islamist extremism in the
same context as the threat of Nazi
Germany and how that was fended off in
the 1940s so there'll be some real
divides and of course in the run-up to
these kind of summits there's an awful
lot of lobbying different groups trying
to encourage their leaders to take one
policy on or another let's try and
understand that a bit better Morrell
Andrews is from an organization called
youth 20 she's joining us live here in
Hamburg high morale and so you and how
many others have been trying to get your
message across 73 delegates from 31
countries altogether okay and you were
telling me you came together earlier in
the month and the idea was that you
found some points of agreement yes we
got together and we negotiated the
policy the 15 main areas that the
Germans have identified as priorities
and we got together and wrote a
communique that was delivered to
Chancellor Angela Merkel and hopefully
our countries will be able to follow up
on that and incorporate that policy in
their g20 communique notice they have
covered quite a few summits over the
years and quite often there's a youth
element attached to the summit there's
sometimes a sense that it's there to
tick a box but perhaps the people with
real power aren't listening what's been
your experience well the fact that
Chancellor Merkel took 90 minutes out of
her day to hear our policies asked us
questions and debate some of the points
it really showed that she cared so it
didn't feel as much that it was just a
box being ticked however we'll be
looking to the outcome of the communique
at the summit in the next few days to
see whether or not youth are recognized
as critical partners or just that box to
tick so what were you telling it to do
well it's we we covered eleven of the
topics so we talked about how youth
unemployment is a huge issue and how
there's a skill gap when
to digitalization and more advanced
economies we reinforce that civil
society strongly supports the Paris
agreement and that countries need to
urgently take priority on the issue of
climate change we talked about refugees
and how we want our societies to be
welcoming and system could be stronger
so that people are able to come in and
thrive in our economy now Donald Trump
would agree with you youth unemployment
is an issue but he would also say that
the best way of protecting jobs is for
countries to protect their own interests
to step away from the kind of free trade
that angle of Merkel supports where did
you reach on that issue well one of the
key points was that we recognized global
trade is an absolute must in the way
that our economy our global economy
works but we need growth that's
inclusive and involves everybody so
avoiding corporations and the rich
population hiding their money away in
tax havens and really looking towards
policy that lifts everybody up as I'm
sure you know not very far from here in
a few hours time there's going to be a
very big protest people who object to
the g20 object the way that we organize
our world what you say to people who
have those profound concerns about the
leaders coming to town I think there's a
definite grievance that people have
raised and it's fabulous that they're
coming out and voicing those concerns
the point is to have it in a peaceful
way and hopefully not have a violent
protest but I think it's great that
youth are getting involved in trying to
hear their voice well thank you very
much indeed Richard just a couple of
points to mention it's absolutely
certain that thousands of protesters are
going to turn out it's also certain for
thousands of police officers here in
Hamburg we'll be keeping an eye on what
they're doing what we don't know is how
that protest is going to play out but of
course we'll keep everyone posted here
on BBC News I think the other point to
make is with this anti-globalization
protest coming up in some ways many of
the leaders who are coming here to
Hamburg accept that the current
iteration of globalization has not been
working that in some ways that
contributed to Donald Trump's victory to
the brexit vote even Emmanuel macron
winning and so the challenge for all of
these leaders is to say alright well if
it's not working for everyone now what's
our response what's fascinating about
this summit is that
Donald Trump and some of the other
leaders fundamentally disagree on what
that response should be
